title: 107_hr4647
content: The Act titled "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act of 2002" allows for the satisfaction of judgments from frozen assets of terrorists, terrorist organizations, and state sponsors of terrorism. The "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act of 2002" allows blocked assets of terrorist parties to be used to satisfy judgments for acts of terrorism, with a provision for Presidential waiver in the interest of national security. The "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act of 2002" allows blocked assets of terrorist parties to be used to satisfy judgments for acts of terrorism, with a provision for Presidential waiver in the interest of national security. The waiver does not apply to property subject to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations or the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations if used for nondiplomatic purposes or if sold or transferred to a third party. The Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include special rules for cases against Iran, allowing for subrogation of judgments prior to October 28, 2000. The Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include special rules for cases against Iran, allowing for subrogation of judgments prior to October 28, 2000. Subsections (e), (f), and (g) are amended, and a new subsection (d) is added regarding the distribution of Foreign Military Sales Funds to compensate for damages awarded in terrorism cases against Iran. The Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include special rules for cases against Iran, allowing for subrogation of judgments. The amount paid to each person is calculated based on compensatory damages awarded. Enforcement of judgments under this subsection is not delayed. The term "terrorist party" refers to a terrorist, terrorist organization, or foreign state designated as a state sponsor of terrorism. A "blocked asset" is any asset seized or frozen by the United States. The terms "property subject to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations or the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations" and "asset subject to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations or the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations" refer to any property or asset that, if attached or executed upon, would violate U.S. obligations under the respective conventions.
